discussion.content: D is correct!

The answer is D!

Reference:

choices.D: Remove both templates and recreate them as updating templates.
choices.B: Remove the VLAN from the Trunk-A template and add the VLAN again.
choices.C: Change the template type of ESXi-Server to an updating template.
choices.A: Change the template type of Trunk-A to an updating template.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Initial template Service profiles created from an initial template inherit all the properties of the template. However, after you create the profile, it is no longer connected to the template. If you need to make changes to one or more profiles created from this template, you must change each profile individually.
Updating template Service profiles created from an updating template inherit all the properties of the template and remain connected to the template. Any changes to the template automatically update the service profiles created from the template.
https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/unified_computing/ucs/sw/gui/config/guide/141/UCSM_GUI_Configuration_Guide_141_chapter28.html

Selected Answer: A
A is the one

Selected Answer: A
its A, Its the vnic template the one where the modification of adding a vlan is made, and if we want that to apply to all server profiles which use this vnic template, it needs to be an updated template.
Right answer is A. You can try to simulate in UCSPE.

Selected Answer: C
I think it is C because the EXSI is using an Initial template and should be using the Trunk-A instead.
D sounds About right as after changing both Service template and vNIC template to updating we can add VLANs to vNIC ad hoc.

right answer could be B. as once the profile has been created from template with 'initial template' enabled, it no longer is associated with the template. so we can't move it from initial to updating and expect changes to reflect in service profile.

questions.question_text: A network engineer is deploying a Cisco All-Flash HyperFlex solution. Which local storage configuration is required for the operating system and persistent logging?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Answer is D, housekeeping and cache

Selected Answer: D
It depends on the version of HX..
Logs= housekeeping disk.
So.. in M6 Hyperflex (newest) there is ssd for housekeeping and ssd for OS..
but in M4 hyperflex the housekeeping datastore is stored on another partition on the SD/Disks that also have ESXi boot partition..

I will go with D.

https://community.cisco.com/t5/storage-networking/hyperflex-installation-location/td-p/3901395

comments.content: but if this is a M4 hyperflex question is just one ssd...

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Using persistent logging allows to write logged messages to file(s) on router's flash disk. The advantage is unlike memory buffer (DRAM) contents these files persist when the router reboots (DRAM contents are erased during a reboot.) Hence if you writing to disk it can run the OS and must wait. So 2 disks as a miniumum.
Answer is A

Selected Answer: D
Based on the All flash nodes, there should be separate SSD drive for logging, thus D makes the most sense.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/unified_computing/ucs/UCS_CVDs/hx_4_vsi_vmware_esxi.html#_Toc41894851

Hostname field:
The hostname or IP address of the location where the backup file is stored.
This can be a server, storage array, local drive, or any read/write media that the fabric interconnect can access through the network.

Remote File field:
The full path to the backup configuration file. This field can contain the filename as well as the path.
If you omit the filename, the backup procedure assigns a name to the file.

Type field:
The information saved in the backup configuration file. 
This can be a binary file that includes a snapshot of the entire system.

Protocol field:
The protocol to use when communicating with the remote server. This can be FTP,TFTP,SCP,SFTP
is correct

https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/unified_computing/ucs/sw/gui/config/guide/141/UCSM_GUI_Configuration_Guide_141_chapter43.html#:~:text=or%20network%20traffic.-,Backup%20Types,the%20system%20during%20disaster%20recovery.

The answer is already Correct
1-Host 2-Remote File 3-Type 4-Protocol

Answer is correct
https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/unified_computing/ucs/sw/gui/config/guide/141/UCSM_GUI_Configuration_Guide_141_chapter43.html

Hostname field The hostname or IP address of the location where the backup file is stored.
Remote File field The full path to the backup configuration file.
Protocol field The protocol to use when communicating with the remote server
Type field The information saved in the backup configuration file
1-remote file 2-type 3-protocol 4-Hostname

questions.question_text:
An engineer configures an Intersight Virtual Appliance and must claim over 200 targets. The engineer starts the Claim New Target Procedure. The engineer has prepared this initial comma-separated value file to provision the targets:
UCSFI,10.1.1.3,user-1,pwd5516b917
IMC,10.1.1.5/26,user-2,pwdc65b1c43f
HX,10.1.2.1/30,user-3,pwd39913690

UCSD,1.1.1.1.user-4,pwd5003e9d5 -
Which information must be included in the comma-separated value file to provision the targets?
